ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This is definitely a different kind of class. Its greatest contribution to the curriculum is the context understood by looking at art, considering culture and history and listening to Professor Draghi's circuitous and delightful stories. This course gets at something deeper than what we encounter elsewhere.

The course was interesting and information, and although it did not follow any particular predefined path, that was not the point. It is very successful, I think, in creating a space where ideas and thinking are encouraged, especially ideas that are not particularly rational or easily described, but that depend on getting a feel for themes, intentions, and environments beneath the surface. In this sense, I think the course is an excellent outlet for important questions that do not receive treatment in other more problem-based policy and science courses.
This course is what you make of it. It also depends on the fellow students taking the course. The visits to museums and library are fascinating.

this course is unique by design - it complemented my other courses well and provoked further investigation of related topicsi would add that the course really comes together nicely at the end - from a set of disparate topics and organic diversions, the point of the class (a thought excercise) becomes clear - a helpful twist to the FES program
Great idea to have a class that discusses art and history and at the same time gives insight on environmental conservation.
The field trips to museums, the discussions, the lectures. They all worked well together.
Beinecke visits, class discussions.
the field trips were extremely valuable and worked well with the course topics and material - especially at the Beinecke
The readings and the books.
One of the best parts was learning the history of Yale, giving us a lot of context about where we are and why we are here.
The fields visits were very useful in illuminating many concepts and discussions

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I think that readings could be more structured in order to encourage greater cohesion in discussions.
Some structure! Project collaborations?
thought im not completely sure of this recommendation - perhaps greater structure for assigned readings? a stricter syllabus?
None that require attention

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: I contacted both, and they were both accessible and incredibly helpful in shaping my project.
professor draghi was available whenever requested and very encouraging to student initiatives, especially wih regard to the final projectsboth TAs were helpful and available as needed
Adequate

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: this course is very unique, by design - it complemented my other courses well

Although archetypes, history of art, and overall history are not my main focus this is a class very valuable for someone that has a Biology background because it gives more sensibility on art themes. Also, this course is of great interest for everybody trying to expand overall culture knowledge.

It is important for context and perspective. I actually think the material and trips we went on should be a part of MODS, because it seems so essential to know these things if you are going to FES or Yale in general.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To become more familiar with the museums and libraries on campus (especially to visit the Beinecke), and to think about ideas that do not picture in most of my other classes.
Opportunity to explore fuzzier aspects of environmental thinking.
personal interest
Because as an international student I took a tour of Yale with Prof. Draghi and he was really good at giving explanations of Yale and history.
I took it for context and perspective.
For gaining an art, theology, culture and mythology oriented perspective on the environment and its interpretation

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, I achieved all of my objectives and learned a great deal.
More or less.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: though it isnt formal 'group work' per se - student contributions to class discussions yielded a great deal over the course of the term

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy the ride and be confident in bringing your interests and concerns to the course. It is a very different course, and one that is what you make of it, so I would really encourage having an open mind or a willingness to explore ideas and spaces.
If you want to do something that you haven't for the lack of time, now you can and get credits too.
follow up on points of interest from class... come in with an open mind and leave with one
Developing the mostoriginal and creative project they can.
Ask questions and participate. The class is what you make it, and we made it pretty darn awesome.
Take it for interesting discussions on arts, religions, mythology and cultural aspects of the environment
